slides.title: The Pattern
slides.bodyText:
In the year of the Great Correction, the Council declared that all human failing could be traced to seven root behaviors. They called these behaviors The Pattern — a doctrine of order imposed upon every citizen.

Pride. Greed. Lust. Envy. Gluttony. Wrath. Sloth.

No longer sins of the soul — now crimes of the state.

slides.title: The Council
slides.bodyText:
The Council rules from the Capital Spire, unseen but omnipresent. Their edicts flow through every bureau, every checkpoint, every surveillance node.

Compliance is measured. Loyalty is tracked. Deviation is catalogued.

The Council does not punish — it corrects. And correction begins with documentation.

slides.title: The Bureau of Pattern Analysis
slides.bodyText:
Within the sprawling bureaucracy, one office holds particular weight: the Bureau of Pattern Analysis.

Its analysts examine evidence, interrogate suspects, and determine which citizens have deviated from The Pattern. Their indictments carry the force of law.

The Bureau does not judge. It classifies.

slides.title: Analyst Marlo
slides.bodyText:
You are Marlo. Pattern Analyst, Third Class.

You have a desk. A set of tools. A stack of cases that arrives each morning.

You have a family that depends on your salary. A landlord who depends on your rent. And a regime that depends on your compliance.

Your job is simple: process the cases. Find the pattern violations. File the indictments.

slides.title: Day One
slides.bodyText:
The morning bell rings at 06:00. Your terminal flickers to life.

A stack of case files sits on your desk. Each one contains evidence, witness statements, and suspect profiles. Your tools are ready — the database, the fingerprint duster, the spectrograph.

Examine. Interrogate. Indict.

The Council is watching. Your family is counting on you.

Begin.
